The paragraph is discussing mutations in the PAX6 gene, specifically truncation mutations in the transactivation region, and the resulting effect of dominant-negative mutants. While there is mention of mutations and their effects, there is no explicit mention of a specific disease.

| Dominant-negative mutants of PAX6 |

The paragraph discusses the effects of dominant-negative mutants, which are a type of genetic mutation. In this context, the mutations are associated with the PAX6 gene. While PAX6 mutations are not explicitly referred to as a disease, they can lead to various eye conditions, such as aniridia or Waardenburg syndrome, depending on the specific mutation. Therefore, the dominant-negative mutants of PAX6 can be considered a type of genetic disease.
